Introduction

Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (PanNETs) are rare neoplasms derived from pancreatic islet cells.  They are classified as functional PanNETs, which secrete peptide hormones and cause specific clinical syndromes (eg, insulinoma, gastrinoma, glucagonoma, VIPoma), and nonfunctional PanNETs.

Epidemiology and pathology

PanNETs are rare.  Although many are sporadic, they can also be associated with hereditary syndromes, including:

  • Multiple endocrine neoplasia 1 (~80%-100% of patients)
  • Von Hippel-Lindau disease (~20% of patients)
  • Neurofibromatosis 1 (~10% of patients)
  • Tuberous sclerosis (~1% of patients)

PanNETs originate from pancreatic islet cells (

figure 1
).  They can vary in size and location and can be solitary or multiple.  Both functional and nonfunctional PanNETs are typically characterized by a well-circumscribed lesion composed of uniform tumor cells with an organoid architecture (eg, nested, glandular, ribbon, or pseudorosette arrangement) (
image 1
).  The cells have round nuclei with characteristic stippled (ie, salt and pepper) chromatin, as well as granular cytoplasm.  Immunohistochemical staining for synaptophysin (protein in neuroendocrine synaptic vesicles) and chromogranin A (protein found within neuroendocrine secretory granules) often shows positive cytoplasmic staining and aids in making the diagnosis (
image 2
).

Overview of clinical presentation

Nonfunctional PanNETs tend to present with symptoms related to tumor enlargement and metastasis (eg, epigastric pain, weight loss, jaundice, palpable mass).

Functional PanNETs present with clinical syndromes consistent with the peptide hormones they secrete.  These PanNETs include:

  • Insulinomas produce insulin, leading to hypoglycemia.
  • Gastrinomas produce gastrin, leading to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) (excessive gastric acid secretion).
  • Glucagonomas produce glucagon, leading to hyperglycemia.
  • VIPoma produces vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria.
  • Somatostatinomas produce somatostatin, leading to various symptoms depending on the affected organs.

They are described in more detail in the following sections.

Insulinoma

Insulinomas are pancreatic beta-cell tumors that secrete insulin autonomously, regardless of blood glucose levels.  They are often solitary and benign but can be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 syndrome.  They are characterized by episodes of hypoglycemia, often occurring during fasting or after meals and accompanied by:

  • Neuroglycopenic symptoms:  sweating, palpitations, tremors, confusion, and seizures
  • Autonomic symptoms:  rapid heartbeat, dilated pupils, and pale skin
  • Cognitive symptoms

Patients usually have high circulating insulin/C-peptide levels.  Diagnosis of insulinomas involves testing for hypoglycemia, such as a 72-hour fast or a mixed-meal tolerance test and localizing the tumor using imaging studies.  Endoscopic ultrasonography may be necessary for pinpointing a more precise localization.  Surgical resection of the tumor may be required.  In cases in which surgery is not possible or effective, medical management with medications such as diazoxide or somatostatin analogs may be necessary.

Gastrinoma

ZES is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors (gastrinomas) that are most commonly located in the small intestine or pancreas (

figure 2
).  The gastrin produced by these tumors stimulates gastric acid production, often resulting in multiple peptic ulcers that can be located beyond the duodenal bulb and are often refractory to therapy.  Patients typically experience abdominal pain and acid reflux.  They may also have diarrhea because gastric acid damages intestinal epithelial cells and inactivates pancreatic enzymes, preventing proper nutrient absorption.

The diagnosis is made by measuring basal and stimulated gastrin levels (secretin stimulation test).  Patients with ZES should undergo testing (eg, serum calcium, prolactin level) to exclude multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 due to the strong association between these conditions.  Note that gastrin can also be elevated due to hypercalcemia or the use of proton pump inhibitors.

Glucagonoma

Glucagonomas arise from the alpha cells of the pancreatic islets of Langerhans and are characterized by the unregulated release of glucagon.  Manifestations reflect the effects of glucagon, which increases amino acid oxidation and has catabolic actions.

Glucagonoma is often diagnosed late in the disease course due to nonspecific early features.

  • Necrolytic migratory erythema (NME) is the presenting feature in ~70% of patients.  NME, likely due to amino acid deficiency, is characterized by painful/pruritic papules that coalesce to form large, indurated plaques with scaling and central clearing on the face, groin, and extremities.
  • The excess glucagon also causes hyperglycemia/diabetes mellitus, although this is usually mild and rarely requires insulin.
  • Other common features include weight loss (catabolic action of glucagon), diarrhea (secretion of glucagon and other molecules [eg, secretin]), venous thromboembolism, and neuropsychiatric symptoms (eg, depression, psychosis).

Laboratory evaluation typically shows normocytic, normochromic anemia, which may be due to anemia of chronic disease or a direct effect of glucagon on erythropoiesis.  A markedly elevated serum glucagon level (>500 pg/mL) confirms the diagnosis.  Although glucagon is increased in other conditions (eg, hypoglycemia, Cushing syndrome, pancreatitis), the elevations are typically mild to moderate.  Abdominal imaging (CT scan or MRI) can localize the tumor and evaluate for metastases.

VIPoma

VIPoma is characterized by excess vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP).  Most affected adults are age 30-50.  VIP binds to intestinal epithelial cells to increase fluid and electrolyte secretion in the intestinal lumen.  Most patients develop VIPoma syndrome (pancreatic cholera) with watery diarrhea (can be tea colored and odorless), muscle weakness/cramps (due to hypokalemia), and hypochlorhydria or achlorhydria (due to decreased gastric acid secretion); this is sometimes referred to as WDHA (watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria) syndrome.  The stool volume can be >3 L/day, leading to significant volume depletion.  Other findings include facial flushing, lethargy, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and weight loss.  Patients can also have coexisting hyperparathyroidism as part of multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome.

Laboratory studies usually show hypokalemia due to increased intestinal potassium secretion.  Other possible findings include hypercalcemia (due to increased bone resorption) and hyperglycemia (due to increased glycogenolysis).  Stool studies are consistent with secretory diarrhea and show increased stool sodium and stool osmolal gap <50 mOsm/kg.  A VIP level >75 pg/mL confirms the VIPoma diagnosis.  Abdominal imaging (cross-sectional triple-phase abdominal CT scan or MRI) can localize the tumor in the pancreas.  Nearly 75% of VIPomas are in the pancreatic tail, and 60%-80% have metastasized to the liver by the time of diagnosis.  Treatment involves intravenous volume repletion, octreotide to decrease diarrhea, and possible hepatic resection in patients with metastasis to the liver.

Somatostatinoma

Somatostatinomas are rare tumors of the pancreatic D cells.  Their manifestations result from somatostatin-induced inhibition of:

  • Insulin, resulting in diabetes mellitus
  • Cholecystokinin, resulting in cholelithiasis
  • Pancreatic enzyme/bicarbonate, resulting in diarrhea/steatorrhea

However, this classic triad (somatostatinoma syndrome) is rarely seen, with most cases presenting with abdominal pain and weight loss.  In patients with somatostatinoma syndrome, an elevated fasting plasma somatostatin level (>3 times the upper limit of normal) is diagnostic.  Surgery is an option for resectable disease.  With unresectable disease, somatostatin analogues can delay the progression.

Summary

Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (PanNETs) are rare neoplasms originating from pancreatic islet cells.  Functional PanNETs often present with characteristic clinical syndromes related to the hormone they produce, including hypoglycemia from insulinomas, Zollinger-Ellison syndrome from gastrinomas, hyperglycemia from glucagonomas, and watery diarrhea with hypokalemia and achlorhydria from VIPomas.  Nonfunctional PanNETs may present with symptoms related to tumor size or spread.  PanNETs can be associated with hereditary syndromes (eg, multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1, neurofibromatosis type 1).
